awd_titl_txt: Who Likes Computer Science? How Gender Stereotypes about Interest Shape Children's Motivation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivation and capacities to pursue careers in the fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) by preparing and interesting elementary- and middle-school students for STEM courses/programs in high school and eventually in STEM careers. This project is significant because it will deepen the understanding of the importance of interest stereotypes (stereotypes about who shows interest in STEM) and how they influence students' motivation to pursue STEM. The project seeks to address the following objectives: (1) to examine how interest stereotypes affect girls' motivation; (2) to study whether interest stereotypes have a stronger negative impact than ability stereotypes on motivation for computer science; and (3) explore whether it is possible to intervene to reduce the impact of interest stereotypes. The findings will have implications for many fields conducting research that aims to reduce educational inequalities linked to stereotypes. This research has the potential to lead to more powerful interventions to help children resist such stereotypes and remain open to pursuing interests in STEM. Another major contribution of this work is to advance social identity theory beyond stereotype threat research on ability stereotypes. The project impact broadens the focus in STEM education by designing real-world interventions that can intervene at the root of the problem to counteract stereotypes and promote STEM motivation. In addition, the project will promote the use of the Open Science Framework to allow free sharing of the data and materials. It will help give students the tools they need to resist interest stereotypes and promote their interest in STEM, help teachers identify the most powerful messages to send their students to boost their motivation for STEM, and use an educational outreach network to connect and share findings broadly, with educators, policymakers, and the entire community of stakeholders working to promote students' motivation in STEM. 

The research will examine how interest stereotypes influence 8-12-year-old children's motivation for computer science. The focus on computer science is due to its low representation of women and highly stereotyped nature. Several experiments will test (a) how interest stereotypes about gender groups impact girls' motivation for novel activities, (b) the impact of interest stereotypes vs. ability stereotypes for computer science activities with girls and boys, and (c) a novel intervention to reduce the impact of interest stereotypes and promote girls' computer science motivation, by linking existing gender differences to environmental structures rather than inherent group differences. The project provides rigorous, theoretically-based research, which is evident through the inclusion of power analysis, reference to previously validated instruments, and reporting of psychometrics. The results will deepen understanding of the importance of interest stereotypes and how they influence children's motivation to pursue STEM, and will lay the groundwork for future interventions that directly target interest stereotypes to boost girls' motivation in computer science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project examined how gender-interest stereotypes influence 8-12-year-old children’s motivation for computer science. We focused on computer science due to its especially low representation of women and highly stereotyped nature. One factor contributing to women’s underrepresentation is societal stereotypes about STEM and gender, which portray women as having lower motivation to pursue STEM.

 

Previous research has primarily examined stereotypes about ability (“which gender has more ability in STEM?”) rather than stereotypes about interest (“which gender likes STEM more?”). This project examined whether interest stereotypes—the sense that one’s group is not interested in an academic field—may be an even more powerful deterrent from choosing to pursue a STEM field than the sense that one’s group does not have as much ability. Three lines of work in this project (involving a total of 873 pilot and study participants) demonstrated that gender-interest stereotypes can cause lower motivation in STEM.

 

Experiments 1A and 1B tested whether interest stereotypes about gender groups have a negative impact on girls’ motivation for novel and computer science activities. These experiments found that 8-9-year-old girls were significantly less interested in and less likely to choose an activity linked to a negative interest stereotype (“girls are much less interested in this activity than boys”), compared to a nonstereotyped activity (“girls and boys are equally interested in this activity,” Studies 3 and 4 of Master, Meltzoff, & Cheryan, 2021, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences). Girls were also significantly less likely than boys to choose the negatively stereotyped activity.

 

Experiment 2 tested the impact of interest stereotypes vs. ability stereotypes for computer science activities with 10-11-year-old girls and boys. This experiment found that children (both girls and boys) were less interested and less likely to choose an activity linked to a negative interest stereotype about their gender compared to a nonstereotyped activity (see Study S1 in the online Supporting Information, Master et al., 2021, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences). However, this condition difference was not found when the stereotype involved ability. Thus, there appears to be something particularly de-motivating about gender-interest stereotypes, compared to ability stereotypes.

 

Experiment 3 tested a novel intervention with 220 11-12-year-old girls to reduce the impact of interest stereotypes and promote computer science motivation, by linking gender differences to malleable environmental structures rather than fixed/inherent group differences. This experiment found that girls who learned about structural factors were less likely to endorse stereotypes favoring boys, and more likely to believe that they could develop their own interest in a STEM activity [Master, A., Cheryan, S., Stier, E., & Meltzoff, A. N. (2022, April). Consequences of teaching girls about structural causes of gender differences in STEM. In J. Gladstone (Chair), Motivational messages to broaden participation in STEM: Important features of messages and messengers. Symposium presented at the American Educational Research Association (AERA).].

 

In terms of intellectual merit, these findings demonstrate that gender-interest stereotypes can have a causal impact on motivation. These findings have implications for many fields conducting research that aims to reduce educational inequalities linked to stereotypes. This research can help lead to evidence-based interventions to help children resist such stereotypes and remain open to pursuing interests in STEM. Another contribution of this work is to advance social identity theory beyond stereotype threat research on ability stereotypes. Here we found that gender-interest stereotypes reduce girls’ sense of belonging in the field of computer science, which contributes to their lower interest in this field, and that these interest stereotypes may be even more pernicious for children than stereotypes about ability.

 

In terms of broader impacts, this project’s findings can help change the design of future interventions to counteract gender-interest stereotypes and promote STEM motivation. All our data are available on the Open Science Framework website, so that other researchers may explore this data as well. This project supported the publication of six journal articles and chapters, as well as 16 conference presentations and invited research talks. Findings have been disseminated broadly to the community of stakeholders working to promote children’s motivation in STEM. Notably, we shared our findings on “Good Morning America” (3.4 M viewers) and by writing an article for The Conversation, which was further distributed by several major newspapers. We also made a specific effort to reach a Latin/South American audience through an interview with BBC Brasil. This project also supported the creation of three visual infographics and one policy brief about motivation and STEM education.
